does anyone here have an opinion on React Native vs Ionic vs "Real" Native Android. Especially as someone like me coming from a web dev background, would it be way easier for me to "just" learn Ionic?

```Wanted to like this. Looks awful. I'm not opposed at all to the intelligent principles which power the underlying mechanism (template and style alongside code in re-usable components, et. al.), but if you want to completely devalue yourself as a mobile client engineer in today's market this is a great way to do it.
>I'm all for it replacing crap WebView-based apps though. Go nuts people who make those awful things…```
^^ Jake Wharton on React Native
Personally, I think Real Native Android >>>>>>>> All
And Ionic is just awful
Yeah, some1 in my company develops Ionic apps
Or well he made an intern app using it. And I absolutely hate it

Ionic == glorified web views
It’s seriously just awful
React Native is way better but I believe still inferior to native android
Also <@U0LE2F29M> if you want to learn mobile, don’t learn ionic. That’s not learning mobile.
<@U0P40THS9|nexusfan> has joined the channel

Thanks for the responses. I guess I was just hoping it would be "quick and easy" for me to create a "mobile app." And having it work cross-platform would be a great bonus. I guess I knew native Android was best for making Android apps. Duh. I'm just trying to gauge how much effort it would take me to learn it all and what my options might be.

If you just want to make an app and you want it to be easy with your current skillset, then sure, use Ionic.  But depending on what the app is doing, it probably won’t be good if it’s super intricate, and you definitely won’t be learning mobile development.

If you want to learn mobile dev,  stay away from Ionic
If you want to make a quick and easy app, sure, use Ionic
yeah. That's what I figured. Thanks

Hi Destiner

<@U0K1ALDQE>: when you say I should use getSupportActionBar(), what does it do when i call that method? Because I used the empty activity layout, I didn’t get an action bar. So, I went on to add a toolbar.
You define a Toolbar in your layout.xml
You get a reference by `findViewById`
You set that Toolbar as SupportActionBar -> ` setSupportActionBar(mToolbar);`
So now when you call `getSupportActionBar()`, you get the correct support action bar, which is the Toolbar you defined in the layout
it just delegates all of the functionality that usually is handled by the activity's actionbar, to the appcompat toolbar
like inflation of menus
not quite everything though, i ran into trouble setting up a contextual action bar the other day
was still possible but needed some extra styling
